div.p: Greetings. I have been afflicted with poor health for more than 14 days and have not yet fully recovered.

Therefore, during this whole time, I have been unable to write anything, nor can I yet compose lengthy letters. You will inform the most illustrious royal legate that I have received his letters and thank him for his faith and diligence, and greet him very kindly. The most distinguished Mr. Coignet was here last Sunday; but due to my infirmity, I could not meet him. He, in his kindness, came to see me and greeted me.

You have no doubt heard the news about the Turkish expedition in Hungary from the most illustrious Mr. Friedrich von Salis, whose letters I received, all written from Vienna, and then the latest ones from Samaden, along with the letters from my son Christoph. I do not reply to him, especially since I expect him or his son to come to me soon, and I reserve the entire conversation for that time. You will greet him and the whole family in my name most kindly.
A messenger sent from Poland has come to us, a minister of Mr. Johannes a Lasco, with extensive letters about the entire state of that kingdom.

Briefly: the sincere preaching of the gospel of Jesus Christ is being propagated in a remarkable manner; but the bishops and clergy are opposing it in a remarkable way. But it has been so arranged from the beginning; this matter is achieved only with the greatest labors.
I also received from that messenger these letters addressed to Mr. Franz Schwarz, which, I pray, you will kindly take care of diligently.
We have nothing from the Netherlands, except that negotiations for peace have begun. May the Lord grant us all that which is salutary.
Live and farewell with Mr. Philipp, Mr. Pontasella, the consuls, and all good people, etc.
The Baden Assembly is not yet finished.
The abbots are plotting something evil, I know not what.
May the Lord, the ruler, look upon the counsels of men and repay each according to His holy judgment, etc. Your Bullinger.
To the most excellent Mr. Johannes Fabricius, faithful minister of the Church of Chur, his compatriot and most beloved brother. Chur.
